trial_identification.studytitle: Aboriginal Smoking Cessation: Randomised trial of support strategies in Aboriginal health services. Be our Ally Beat Smoking (BOABS) Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial in Indigenous Australian clients of primary health care services of a twelve month intensive multidimensional smoking cessation intervention with a primary end point of sustained cessation at twelve months from the beginning of the intervention.

interventions.interventions: One year intensive primary healthcare-based, Aboriginal researcher-led multidimensional smoking cessation program individualised smoking cessation plan; regular personal contact & counselling (12-14 individual sessions); monthly group sessions; and support to assist access to existing smoking cessation, health and other services.
interventions.comparator: Regional best practice clinic based smoking cessation program following Kimberley Smoking Cessation Protocol

primaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of participants who are not smoking tobacco as determined by urinary cotinine level
Proportion of participants who are not smoking tobacco as determined by self-report
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 months after randomisation 12 months after randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of participants who report 20% or greater reduction in the number of cigarettes smoked each week
Proportion of participants reporting excellent or very good health using a self-reported health questionnaire

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Self-reported current smoker Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander A regular client of the health service Considering quitting smoking soon / within the next 30 days (READY stage)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unable to provide informed consent A health condition that would prevent them from completing the trial Unlikely to be available for follow up at 12 months

trial_design.concealment: People attending the primary care services who meet the eligibility criteria will be provided with information about the trial and if they give informed consent to participate will have the initial questionnaire completed. The Research Asssistant (RA) at the trial site will then contact the holder of the allocation schedule based at the central administration site who will then allocate to intervention or control group based on the randomisation list (see below).
trial_design.sequence: Computer-generated randomisation table created by computer software (i.e., computerised sequence generation) with block stratification by study site.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Aboriginal people smoke at much higher rates than non-Aboriginal people and smoking is an important contributor to increased disease, hospital admissions and deaths in Aboriginal populations. Quit smoking programs in Australia have not had the same impact on Aboriginal smokers as on non-Aboriginal smokers and Aboriginal people are twice as likely to smoke as non-Aboriginal people. It is important that improved techniques for assisting Aboriginal people to quit be developed and implemented as part of comprehensive strategies to improve Aboriginal health. A range of strategies have been used to encourage Aboriginal people to quit smoking however there have been few good quality studies that show what approaches work best. More evidence of strategies that could work more widely in Aboriginal primary health care settings is needed if good policy is to be developed and implemented. This trial will be based in two major Aboriginal health services in the Kimberley region of Western Australia and run over three years. Participants who agree to participate will be randomly allocated to either a program following current Australian recommended primary care smoking cessation strategies or a more intensive supported quit smoking intervention.
